headline: Inside Politics
subHeadline: Hunter Biden Calls Out "Political Weaponization" Of His Addiction In Emotional USA Today Op-Ed; New Poll: RFK Jr. Gets 22 Percent In Matchup With Trump And Biden; Top U.S. Intelligence Officials Assess Iran And Its Proxies Want To Avoid Wider War With Israel. Aired 12:30-1p ET

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN FOER, STAFF WRITER, THE ATLANTIC
utterances.sentences: So Joe Biden's interests and Hunter Biden's interests are not totally aligned here, and they never really have been. Hunter Biden in this split screen set against everything else that's going on in the world is fighting this battle for his reputation that part of the reason that he's not settled his case thus far is that he has his own set of interests. He doesn't want to be prosecuted if Donald Trump returns to power.He wants to be rehabilitated in the public's eyes. And he is being smeared. But there are other choices he could make along the way that would help his case disappear and his instinct is to really fight hard and fight back.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: His instinct is to fight hard and fight back, and my understanding is that he has been -- and you sort of alluded to this -- incredibly frustrated that he's being attacked because he's the son of a president. But because he's the son of a president, he doesn't feel like he can defend himself in a way that he wants to, which is what made this op-ed really interesting because I know it's been a long time coming.

utterances.speaker: MJ LEE, CNN SENIOR WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes. And you know, I don't think there are many issues for President Biden that are sort of more sensitive than this one. The issue of his son, all of the struggles that he has confronted. Obviously, something that a family, if you're at the White House, you can't afford to deal with these issues in private.You know, what White House aides will say is that the president himself genuinely does believe that this is a scenario, this is a case where he is seeing his son be sort of politically and unfairly maligned. At the same time, yes, there is recognition that this is sort of the newer strategy for Hunter Biden, and that is to go on the offensive. That is to make his voice heard, whether it's through an op-ed or writing a book.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Or hiring a new lawyer.

utterances.speaker: LEE
utterances.sentences: Right, have a new legal strategy and legal team and sort of make the case for himself as a private citizen. But, you know, as you were saying, that's when you sort of get into, are you being just the son of the president or are you looking out for your own interests? And I think you can't really separate out the two.

utterances.speaker: MARGARET TALEV, CNN POLITICAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: I mean, there are benefits to being the son of a president. Hunter Biden would never have been in a position to be able to get many of the roles or clients in the lobbying world or art clients or so and so forth if not also being the son of a president.I think like many figures in public life, you have the ability and maybe the need to fight your battles on a parallel front, the legal front and the social front. Even though this may not be about or coordinated in any way with the Biden campaign's reelection campaign, I actually see some sort of places where they do align, which is because there are millions of Americans, millions of Americans --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TALEV
utterances.sentences: -- whose lives are touched by opioid addiction. And they tend to live in important states like New Hampshire --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TALEV
utterances.sentences: -- in the Rust Belt, in swing states, in --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE) unfortunately. TALEV

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I want to play -- you both alluded to this -- what President Biden has said about his son. This is a moment back in the 2020 presidential debate.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: Hunter got thrown out of the military. He was thrown out, dishonorably discharged.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: That's not true. He wasn't dishonorably discharged.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: -- for cocaine use. And he didn't have a job until you became vice president. Once you became --

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: None of that is true.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: He made a fortune in Ukraine, in China, in Moscow --

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: That is simply not true.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: -- and various other places.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: My son --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: He made a fortune.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: My son --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: And he didn't have a job.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: My son, like a lot of people, like a lot of people, you know, at home had a drug problem. He's overtaken it. He's fixed it. He's worked on it. And I'm proud of him. I'm proud of my son.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: But why was he given --(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: A new poll shows independent candidate Robert Kennedy Jr. gaining in a three-way race with President Biden and former President Trump. To help me break this down, what it means, or maybe -- I don't know if it means anything, our panel is back with us.So let's look at what we're talking about here. This is from Quinnipiac, the Q poll as it's known. Joe Biden, 39 percent, Donald Trump, 36 percent, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. 22 percent. Now let's just go a little deeper into independent voters. Joe Biden, 30 percent, Donald Trump, 31 percent, Kennedy, 36 percent. A third, a third, a third. Now let's do the caveat. And the caveat is that this early in the race, voters tend to say, I'm going to go with the independent because they're just annoyed at their choices from both parties. It's still a pretty stark number --

utterances.speaker: LEE
utterances.sentences: Yes --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: -- if you're the Biden campaign.

utterances.speaker: LEE
utterances.sentences: It's early. There's not a lot of polling on this. But I do think we have already seen both sides take this candidacy seriously enough, like you're hearing Republicans, Democrats saying, well, here are all the reasons why you shouldn't take this guy seriously.Is he really a Democrat? Is he actually a Republican? I think that if you are the Biden campaign, just to point out the obvious, yes, the issue is that the candidate is unpopular, the candidate being President Biden he has a serious enthusiasm problem. So if you're in a situation where anybody can even take even just a sliver of voters away from you, whether it's young people who are just not enthusiastic, whether it's, you know, Democrats who are just kind of curious about the Kennedy name --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Kennedy curious.

utterances.speaker: LEE
utterances.sentences: Kennedy curious, yes, that's going to actually add up and be really problematic.

utterances.speaker: FOER
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, what will be so interesting is that they're likely to be -- it's not just a third party, there's going to be a third or fourth and a fifth party this year. You use Cornel West --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Right. Which -- by the way, he's at 6 percent at this point.

utterances.speaker: FOER
utterances.sentences: And then there's going to possibly be a new -- no labels. Candidate representing the center in some sort of way and Bobby Kennedy Jr. And then who knows how this cuts in different states or if it hurts Biden more than it hurts Trump. It's so hard to say at this early stage.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: And we should also note that it's not like the easiest thing in the world to get on the ballot.

utterances.speaker: FOER
utterances.sentences: Yes, in particularly, in every state has different rules and timelines, but in some of the states that will determine who the president is, maybe challenging.

utterances.speaker: TALEV
utterances.sentences: Yes. This poll doesn't show that Robert Kennedy is going to be the next president of the United States, but it does show the potential for a spoiler or multiple spoiler candidates, especially when you have two men who are the standard bearers of their party heading toward the nomination for whom there's a huge amount of controversy on one side and a fair amount of apathy on the other side.And so I think it's something to watch. It's something that bears watching and it also reflects independence and younger people and in general a societal trend where people don't like the two party system anymore, but there's no mechanism to break it. And with each cycle, things move --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TALEV
utterances.sentences: -- further towards the bases and nobody knows what to do. And so, some third party option is the closest to a protest vote people think they have.
